page.title: 11LANDSCAPE 1
page.content: {ARCHITECTURE:}There are quite a number of 16th and 17th Century buildings surviving in the area. Some of the{Tudor}half-timbered houses are hard to spot because of (usually Georgian) alterations. Within, the oak rafters and panelling are proudly displayed. Later houses built in red brick with "Flemish Gables" and peg-tile roofs are to be found. At Grays and elswhere there are fine example of {Georgian}architectural style as applied to farmhouses. Marshside Methodist Chapel, and cottages at Boyden Gate are Victorian. Buildings of the 1920s and 1930s are noticably lacking, perhaps due to the deep slump in farming during that period. An exception is the fine{Road {House}at Hawthorn Corner.
